content.description: Start under a large, nearly square white block that leads up to the left side of the same ledge shared by Twins Left. Move up and left into some good holds and a horizontal crack. Move up through the path of least resistance towards a green plant/bush and then the belay rings. Please do not harm the plant. There is also an alternate start to the left near the large flake leaning against the wall. This is by no means a perfect route and still needs some cleaning so just play around and have a little fun. That is what it is supposed to be about in the first place.
content.protection: Top-rope. Belay rings at the top.
content.location: To the left of the two Twins routes.

content.description: Climb on a slanting flake which leads to a few thins moves and a roof.  Pull the roof on good holds, get high feet and layback a flake to reach the lip.  Find some good holds to precariously move up to the last bolt.  Slowly work your feet up and stand up to a thumbercling to clip the anchors.

climbs.name: The Twins Left
climbs.fa: Unknown. Trad - J. O'Connell & T. Mabe 2010 in its previous state.

content.description: At one time, this was one of the better moderates on this wall. During the removal of loose rock in late 2013 most of the holds on the middle section were removed. This was a wonderful 5.8 jug haul. No one will ever get to experience the route as it once was and that is a shame. The start is several feet left of Twins Right and climbs straight up to a small ledge that is just left of the ramp on the neighboring route. The two routes originally come together for a moment and split at the small roof. Now, Twins Left heads straight up towards the anchors through some steeper rock with far less holds than the route to the right. It is a bit more direct than Twins Right. The routes were near mirror images of each other in the middle and were of equal grade, hence the names. It is still a decent line but will probably stay a top-rope route. We actually climbed it on trad gear back before knocking off holds. Some of the gear placements later pulled right off, so they probably would not have held in a fall.
content.protection: Top-rope only. Ring anchors at the top.
content.location: Near the middle of the left wall. Directly beside the bolted Twins Right.

content.description: Work your way up to a small corner and then through easier ground to a slightly steeper section.  Stay left of the bolts and stand up to gain easier ground and the shuts.
This route at first appears straight forward but is actual a bit thought provoking.
content.location: This is the first route on the Upper Ledge after the scramble.

climbs.name: Original Route Direct
climbs.fa: Unknown - possibly Steve Pope. Bolted and climbed by J. O'Connell in 2014.

content.description: This is a recently bolted line that was meant to provide an easier lead for those not ready to tackle the tougher stuff. Follow the bolt line past five bolts to a set of rings below a massive block. Be creative when climbing as there are multiple options. The only difficulty will be the final moves to the ledge under the rings. If you are tall, this will be very easy. However, shorter climbers will have some difficulty and the grade is dependent on height. If you are not into mantles, avoid this route.
content.protection: Five bolts leading to ring anchors.
content.location: Starts on the ramp that provides access to the Upper Ledge, above the Top-Rope Buttress.

content.description: Scramble up onto the access ramp for the Top Rope Buttress and begin at the step-like blocks just to the left of The Streaks. Some people are using this as a start for The Streaks also. Follow the ledges to a chimney behind a large block. There are rings located under the block. Climb straight up into the chimney and wiggle your way to the top. The anchors are a short distance from the top of the chimney. There are muliple starts and finishes that can be used also, be creative. Try laybacking the  outer edge of the chimney, rather than climbing into it, for a stiff 5.8 variation. You can even climb directly over the center of the block. This was a trad/solo climb but trad is currently being frowned upon in the park so please repect the park rules until further notice.
content.location: Far right side of the Left Wall, just left of The Streaks.

content.description: Will add more detail for this this the next time I climb it*
content.protection: 4 bolts to bolted anchors with rappel rings.
content.location: Between Old Man's Brow TR and the Twins Right.

content.description: Climb up to a thin move out left and into some rotton rock.  Pull a small buldge on the left side and then traverse right to reach a massive shark tooth jug hold.  Move up into the final roof and figure out how to reach the lip.  Once at the lip search around for a good incut out right to help pull over.  Stand up on the ledge and continue up and left on a slanting flake to reach the top of the cliff just left of the anchors.

Layback Flakes is an old trad line that is not bolted.

Climb broken flake system of several, roofish jutting flakes.  Once you get over the last sloping mantel its a easy skip to the anchors.
content.protection:
This is the old trad line

Update - The Park has decided not to allow trad climbing at all so please leave your trad gear at home. It is now Top-Rope only until further notice.
content.location: Near the parking lot, Near the access ramp to access the 2 tier.

content.description: Start on the right side of the anchors and climb to the right of the first two bolts. Do not start on Sunny Day. The first two bolts are not in the most ideal locations but it was the best rock at the time. We cannot just stick bolts into any rock as much of it is not of the best quality. Follow the corner to the right of the first bolt up to a good stance under a slight overhang. There is a really nice side-pull on the ledge, a few feet right of the second bolt. Step up on the hold near the bolt and then up to the ledge. Traverse left, just past the third bolt and climb the right edge of the large block. Move just past the fourth bolt, to where the horizontal cracks can be reached. Stick your right foot into an obvious dish and swing the left foot up over the top of the ledge. Under-cling the uppermost horizontal to clip the rings. The rings were placed as far right as possible to allow other climbers to still be able to use Sunny Day. If there are not other climbers on Sunny Day, or climbers waiting, it is ok to use the anchors that were previously shared by both routes. This route was mistakenly called Layback Flakes, which was one of the early routes in this section. We are not completely certain of the original line but it most likely was closer to Sunny Day. This line is not a 5.8 so don't get excited. We climbed it for years on trad gear since it had decent pro but it is fairly certain that Steve Pope and crew had already climbed all of this rock. After installing the anchors, I did rope solo it a couple of times to test the clips. It is really easy so a 5.6 rating is a bit more accurate.
content.protection: 4 bolts and rings at the top.
content.location: Between Sunny Day and Original Route Direct.
